conclusion: The problem involves a spring-mass system, a circular arc, and frictional forces, and requires the use of conservation of mechanical energy and the law of cosines.
Known values are: height of platform \( h = 0.53 \, \text{m} \), radius of arc \( R = 0.4 \, \text{m} \), angle \( \theta = 37^\circ \), \( \sin 37^\circ = 0.6 \), \( \cos 37^\circ = 0.8 \).
The initial vertical displacement of the slider at point \( B \) is calculated as \( h_{B} = h - R \sin \theta = 0.53 - 0.4 \times 0.6 = 0.39 \, \text{m} \).
The horizontal distance between points \( B \) and \( C \) is \( x_{BC} = 0.9 \, \text{m} \), and the segment \( AB \) is at its maximum length.
The horizontal distance \( x_{AB} \) is determined as \( x_{AB} = 2 \times x_{BC} = 1.8 \, \text{m} \).
The initial horizontal velocity of the slider at point \( B \) is calculated as \( v_{B} = \sqrt{2gh_{B}} = \sqrt{2 \times 0.53 \times 0.39} = \sqrt{0.396} \).
The law of cosines is used to find the velocity \( v_{C} \) of the slider at point \( C \).
The equation \( v_{C}^2 = v_{B}^2 + v_{B}^2 - 2 \times v_{B} \times v_{B} \times \cos \theta \) is set up using the law of cosines.
Substitute known values into the equation: \( v_{C}^2 = (\sqrt{0.396})^2 + (\sqrt{0.396})^2 - 2 \times \sqrt{0.396} \times \sqrt{0.396} \times 0.8 \).
Simplify the equation: \( v_{C}^2 = 0.396 + 0.396 - 0.396 \times 0.8 \), resulting in \( v_{C}^2 = 0.396 \).
The law of cosines is used again to find the angle between the velocity and the horizontal direction when the slider lands at point \( C \).
